issues.description: The problem statement and UML explicitly require a method named checkOrderReady() on SealSaloon (used by orderMeal() to attempt serving queued orders). The solution implementation instead defines a method named processOrders() and orderMeal() calls processOrders(). This is a signature/name mismatch for a core method students are expected to implement (and tests/instructions reference checkOrderReady()). The discrepancy in method name can confuse students about which method to implement and may cause automated checks or student expectations (based on the problem text/UML) to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution and template consistent with the problem statement by providing a method named checkOrderReady() on SealSaloon (with the signature public void checkOrderReady()). If the implementation logic is in processOrders(), rename that method to checkOrderReady() or add a public checkOrderReady() that delegates to processOrders(). Ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady() as described in the problem text/UML.

issues.description: The problem statement requires a SealSaloon method named checkOrderReady() (used by orderMeal to attempt serving queued orders). In the solution implementation this behavior is provided by a method named processOrders(), and the template repository does not contain a SealSaloon.java to show the expected name. This creates a naming mismatch: students reading the problem will implement/check for checkOrderReady(), but the reference solution uses a different identifier (processOrders()), causing confusion about the required API and where to place/which method to call.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name with the problem statement. Rename the solution method processOrders() to checkOrderReady(), and ensure orderMeal() calls checkOrderReady(). Alternatively, add a checkOrderReady() wrapper that delegates to processOrders() so the API matches the specification while preserving internal naming.
